ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained insight into analyzing the current literature in economic research concerning income inequality and how it can be measured effectively. I think in particular this course offers great insights into how to understand and systematically divide a paper into its various conclusions.
Very good survey of current literature on economics and mobility.

I was able to practice my econometrics and R skills to the problem sets and projects that were assigned throughout the course. Although, I was aware of the different types of economic inequality, this helped dive deeper in and expose to some fascinating research papers that furthered my understanding of the this subject.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The assignments are a lot tougher than they seem. 

Little to no feedback on assignment. 

Prof. is amazing though. He is direct but kind and approachable. 

Attendance to the class was low.

The course is a bit difficult to remain attentive to because a lot of the material is simply going over the work already done in the field. I don't know how this can really be improved because it seems to be the main intention of the course to begin with.

Strengths is the fair amount of work given to the students in the course. The combination of problem sets, a project, and a presentation was a nice aspect of the course; it helped us work with the material in different ways. A weakness was the recordings of lectures, since it did not show the slides that the the professor was using to teach.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to a student who wishes to have a big deep dive into this particular kind of economic research. The breadth of material covered is quite expansive and offers a lot of good insights into the world of economic research more generally, but the course suffers from the fact that it isn't about replicating the research so much as just understanding it. This fact makes it difficult to remain engaged with the course at times.
Yes, I would, especially if interested in labour economics. Fills an important niche at Yale.
